I don't understant why in the first problem he drew the entire tree since we only need to find the conditional probability given victory in the first game. the probability should only be 2/3 (for victory in the second game) + 1/3(loss in the second game)*1/3(victory in the third game) = 7/9 and we don't need to apply the formulae.

All over the world Computer Scientist plays a very important part in this industry, There are many other things in this world  that probability is at the forefront.

so basically for any probabilistic question, draw the tree such that all possibilities are written down with their corresponding probabilities. so, fair coin or non fair coin is 1/2. for the fair coin, it can be H or T, both 50% chance. go through all possibilities. next, the endpoints should be such that they are the multiplication of all the odds in the previous lines.  then make a diagram to find out the what the probability of A AND B is and what prob of B is. Then plug into the formule P(A AND B)/ P(B) and that;s ur answer :)

I believe it might be easier to get a better intuitive understanding if you think of it as the same dice rolled three times. If you roll the dice once you would have 1/6, If you were given 3 chances to roll the same dice it would not still be 1/6. It would certainly be higher than 1/6, But as professor Tom said to have to be careful when using intuition

Ok I can answer myself after some more thinking: the major problem with covid tests would be false negatives, and those have much less effect if p is low. From his example, computing the opposite case P(A|B) where A = is actually healthy, and B = test is negative, the result is 98%. That should be tweaked knowing the exact false negative ratio, and considering that p is the ratio of ill people among the ones taking the test, so it could be a little higher than actual ratio in population.

Suppose, you have a fair coin. Either Head or Tail. You flip it, get Head. Does that mean P(Head) = 1? NO! Its an outcome, which has a probability of 0.5.
There is a name for this bias called "participation bias". I don't really know much, but it does seem to skew up data.

Actually, you didn't subtract. Let's think of it this way:  You had 2*2*2=8 sample points in your sample space. Two of them, WWL and WWW has a probability of 0. Why? Because there is a condition that after the first two wins the series ends.  So, those two sample points WWL and WWW never occur, hence the probability is zero. What is the probability of getting a 7 in a fair regular die? Zero.

My apologies. My previous reply was not the right interpretation. So I'll go a long way with my reshaped interpretation. You had 2*2*2=8 sample points. That is true. Which are, in probability space Sp={WWW(2/9), WWL(1/9), WLW(1/18), WLL(1/9), LWW(1/9), LWL(1/18), LLW(1/9), LLL(2/9)}; Now there are two events: "A": win the series, "B": win the first game. In terms of sets, A={WWW, WWL, WLW, LWW}, B={WWW, WWL, WLW, WLL}. Now you never see WWW, WWL, LLW, LLL; because, after two consecutive W or L, the series ends with a result. So you combine WWW(2/9)+WWL(1/9) which gives you WW(1/3), and LLW(1/9)+LLL(2/9) which gives you LL(1/3). So, the probability space becomes Sp={WW(1/3), WLW(1/18), WLL(1/9), LWW(1/9), LWL(1/18), LL(1/3)}. You didn't subtract anything, you just merged 4 of them into 2.
